author: Megan Neil
title: Home deposit a hopeless quest for young, single | Business News | Business and Finance News | |
text:
SINGLE people on an average income have no hope of ­quickly saving a deposit to buy their first home, according to research.
Getting a deposit together quickly is probably unrealistic even for couples where both earn the average wage, unless parents can help out, Canstar spokeswoman Justine Davies says.
“The percentage of salary that would need to be set aside to get into the housing market quickly is very unrealistic for most people,” Ms Davies said yesterday.
“You might be able to do the hard yards for a couple of years and get a five to 10 per cent ­deposit but to try and to do that to achieve a 20 per cent deposit I think for most people is going to be unrealistic.”
In Melbourne, based on ­average house prices and wage levels, a couple would need to set aside 29 per cent of their net income to raise a 5 per cent deposit within a year.
A single woman would need to set aside 69 per cent, according to research by the financial comparison group, and a single man 49 per cent.
The figures are based on a median house price in ­Melbourne of $527,500 and ­average net monthly ­incomes of $3171 for women and $4454 for men.
Sydney was a more challenging market still, Ms Davies said.
A Sydney couple on average wages would have to set aside 41 per cent of their net income to raise a 5 per cent deposit in a year.
Extending that to a standard 20 per cent deposit would take several years, unless the couple could get a kickstart from their parents.
“Really I think a 20 per cent deposit, unless you receive a financial windfall or ... you both have extremely well-paying jobs, it’s really not achievable for first-home buyers,” Ms Davies said.
Even outside Melbourne and Sydney, it would probably take about five years to save a 20 per cent deposit, she said.
“If you were determined to save a 20 per cent deposit and you were wanting to buy in Sydney particularly or even Melbourne and you’re on an average income, then I think in order to pay your other ­expenses you’re going to be looking at at least six, seven, eight years to get a 20 per cent ­deposit.”
A couple on average incomes would have to save 26 per cent of their net pay towards a deposit in Brisbane, the Canstar research shows.
Ms Davies said that was probably a more sustainable amount to be able to put aside but it would still be difficult on an average income.
AAP
Originally published as Home deposit a hopeless quest for young, single
